title-group.article-title: Rhetoric as Idea: D. H. Lawrence's Genre Theory

abstract.p: It has been over ten years since anything significant has been published on D. H. Lawrence's critical prose, and nothing of note has ever been written on the subject of the short essays—“The Novel,” “Surgery for the novel—Or a Bomb,” “Morality and the Novel,” and “Why the novel Matters”—containing his theory of the novel. The rhetorical style Lawrence adopts is so informal, so comical, and often so bizarre that the impulse of critics, when they do refer to these essays, is to ignore the rhetoric and somehow extract a system of logocentric doctrine, a doctrine that does not bear scrutiny. To appreciate Lawrence's genre theory, one cannot ignore the style in which it is written but must instead focus on the dynamics of discourse comprising the rhetorical text. Grounding my reading in Bakhtin'scarnival, I argue that Lawrence celebrates the novel in terms of its “joyful relativity” (Bakhtin's term), a theory that articulates itself performatively in different ways through its own deconstruction. Read deconstructively, Lawrence's genre theory offers an important contribution to modernist concepts of language, an area from which Lawrence has traditionally been entirely excluded.

Although my use of the term “genre theory” throughout this essay refers to Lawrence's critical thinking about thenovelas genre, not about the nature of literary genre in general, his ideas about the novel generally express, or can be inferred to express, a comparison with other generic forms.

The best known of those who do is David Gordon. In his book, now over 30 years old, Gordon includes an introduction, reprinted in Bloom's Chelsea House volume, summarizing Lawrence's genre theory. On Lawrence as a critic, Peter Bein, Howard Mills, Garry Watson, and René Wellek have all written important essays that have included introductory references to his theories about the novel.

This is, I believe, the crucial difficulty with all the critics (except Howard Mills) cited in note 3. They base their analyses of Lawrence's criticism entirely on what they summarize as Lawrence set beliefs about the novel as form. They quote a line or a passage from one of Lawrence's essays (generally without identifying the particular essay) and translate what Lawrence is “saying” there. None of them analyzes the critical essays separately, as specific contexts for the beliefs they summarize— David Gordon even extracting Lawrentian genre theoryverbatimout of narrative commentary in Lady Chatterley's Lover (119)—but all treat his “sayings” as the definitive Lawrentian philosophy on the novel as a form. More problematic still is that, as often happens, critics take Lawrence's statements about genre and force hisnovelsto fit them.

That there also would seem to be a limit to how many times the theory can be productively presented in this way might account for the lack of recent interest in Lawrence's criticism—it has been “covered.”

Interestingly, while Lawrence shares Aristotle's preference for metaphor over simile because it is so immediate, James and Woolf stylistically rely more on simile in constructing their genre theories. In this way, these other novelists demonstrate through their rhetorical style a closer one-to-one correlation between the novel and material reality than Lawrence does, this despite their shared horror of the novel as realistically mimetic in form.

Although some recent work on Lawrence has acknowledged the comedy in his fiction (see Eggert and Worthen , Lawrence and Comedy ), this quality has been so well buried as to have heretofore gone mostly unrecognized. The same is not true with Lawrence's nonfiction prose; there, his sense of humor is right up front, pervasive, and functional.
See, for example, David Gordon, 11-12, and K. K. Sharma, 99, both of whom insist that these inconsistencies result from Lawrence's tendency to say things that he didn't really mean.

Although Isobel Findlay points to the legitimacy of reading Lawrence's critical prose deconstructively, she does so only by pointing to specific statements made by Lawrence about the novel as a genre that suggest he would be amenable to such an approach; she does not actually deconstruct the genre theory itself or explain why it might be the best way to understand his thinking or his process of representing that thinking. A much more useful analysis is E. Elizabeth's Wallace's explanation for what she considers Lawrence's deliberate use of contradictions in his epistemological writings and, by implication, thevalueof a deconstructive reading of his prose.

For fuller arguments on deconstructing metaphor in Lawrence, see Doherty's
“White Mythologies: D. H. Lawrence and the Deconstructive Turn”and“The Art of Leaping: Metaphor Unbound in D. H. Lawrence'sWomen in Love”and Hagen's
“The Metaphoric Foundation of Lawrence's ‘Dark Knowledge.’”

I have not been arguing that Lawrence carefully and deliberately worked out the exact wording of his criticism so that it would perform all of the specific rhetorical maneuverings that my analysis points out. Rather, like all deconstructive readers, I try to acknowledge what Lawrenceallowshis rhetoric to do to the logocentrisms it articulates. As Jonathan Culler says,“Deconstructive readings that show philosophical texts deconstructing their own arguments and identifying their own strategies as rhetorical impositions in effect credit these texts with what is better called knowledge than ignorance”(183).

One notable exception is E. Elizabeth Wallace. In her important “The Circling Hawk,” Wallace describes the style and substance of Lawrence's epistemological writing as alwaysin processand alwaysin characterand explores the implications of that fact to the conceptualizing of his doctrine. See, especially, 110.

Bakhtin maintains that while double-voiced discourse is often made use of in rhetorical prose—as in parody for example—its function is primarily cosmetic, for it serves the purpose of dressing up what is still a single-voiced authoritative idea ( Dialogic Imagination
